overview.short: Kocuria species are Gram-positive cocci (often in tetrads, pairs, or clusters), aerobic to facultatively anaerobic, catalase-positive, and typically part of skin and oral flora.
overview.clinical_context: Usually opportunistic; may be recovered from blood cultures, catheter-associated infections, skin/soft tissue sites, and immunocompromised patients. Can be mistaken for coagulase-negative staphylococci or Micrococcus.

field_notes.Pigment: Many Kocuria produce cream to pink/orange colonies; intensity varies by species and conditions.
field_notes.Oxidase: May be variable depending on method and strain.
field_notes.NaCl Tolerant (>=6%): Some strains tolerate higher salt; not consistently genus-defining.

key_differentiators.notes: Helps exclude S. aureus when Gram-positive cocci in clusters are seen.
Pigmented colonies (pink/orange) can point toward Micrococcaceae (Kocuria/Micrococcus).
Non-motility supports Kocuria vs certain motile Gram-positive cocci.

common_confusions.reason: Similar Gram-positive cocci and catalase positivity; coagulase-negative staphylococci can look very similar.
Same family-level phenotype; both can be pigmented and form tetrads.

when_to_question_identification: Coagulase positivity strongly suggests Staphylococcus aureus rather than Kocuria.
Marked beta haemolysis argues against typical Kocuria.
Repeated isolation from sterile site with consistent phenotype should prompt definitive ID (MALDI-TOF/16S).

recommended_next_tests.reason: Rules out S. aureus when clusters are observed.
Supports Micrococcaceae vs staphylococci depending on lab workflow.
Most reliable separation of Kocuria vs Micrococcus and species-level calls.
Useful confirmatory method if MALDI is ambiguous or clinically significant isolate.
